Description: Body sherd of South Ionian (probably Milesian) Wild Goat Style pottery closed vessel, an amphora or oinochoe; exterior, white slip; from top, part of animal frieze (belly, one foreleg, and one hind leg of goat remaining) to right; dot rosette, four-lobed rosette, and compartmentalised triangle as filling ornament; wide black band between narrow black bands; second animal frieze to right (body, neck, and part of legs of grazing goat remaining); pin wheel rosette, dot rosette, and four-petalled rosette as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Also published in Lemos 1991, Pl. 50, 345, wrongly as Chian.

Lemos describes the sherd as having a Chian origin and classifies it in her Group of the Aphrodite Bowl with dating of circa 600 BC because the sherd displays a greater amount of variety in the filling ornaments (Lemos 1991, p. 74-5). Deer and does are extremely rare in Chian pottery but much more common on South Ionian vases.
Bibliographic references: Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 111, pl. XXXIV, no. 321.13)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 75, p. 249, no. 345, pl. 50)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 92-3, Nau 35, pl. 8g)
Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 214, no. 35)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.035)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5981 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
